parameters.result: a factor with levels Died Injured
parameters.gender: a factor with levels Female Male
parameters.mode:
mode of transportation,
a factor with levels 4-Wheeled Bicycle Motorcycle Pedestrian

description:
Description
Bertin (1983) used these data to illustrate the cross-classification of 
data by numerous variables, each of which could have various types
and could be assigned to various visual attributes.
For modeling and visualization purposes, the data can be treated as a
4-way table using loglinear models and mosaic displays, or as a 
frequency-weighted data frame using a binomial response for
result ("Died" vs. "Injured") and plots of
predicted probabilities.
title: Traffic Accident Victims in France in 1958
reference:
age is an ordered factor, but arguably, mode should be treated as ordered, with levels
Pedestrian < Bicycle < Motorcycle < 4-Wheeled 
as Bertin does.  This affects the parameterization in models, so we don't do this directly in the
data frame.
format:
A data frame in frequency form (comprising a 5 x 2 x 4 x 2 table)
with 80 observations on the following 5 variables.
